text:
Hello all!

I am starting the Dev course and have a question about creating the sandbox. If I move forward with creating the sandbox, will it affect anything with my company’s current setup? I am currently a user of our company account.

Do you mean the "enterprise sandbox" option?
I'd say no but you never know.

Something I always recommend to every fellow developer: Create a free <https://developers.HubSpot.com/get-started|CMS dev account> (select Create CMS developer Sandbox account) which will be completly seperated from any live account
Thank you! Do you have any other resources for learning about creating custom modules? I am going to edit and build landing page modules for my company.
Hi <@U01QVR44MEY>: I’m in the HubSpot dev bootcamp and missed last week’s (week 2) session. Do you have the recording so I can go through the exercises before tomorrow?

Sure - imo the best way to start is this:
• if you haven't - complete the <https://academy.HubSpot.com/courses/cms-for-developers|CMS for developers certification> in the HubSpot academy - this will give you a good understanding how HubSpot themes and custom modules are working
• bookmark the <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/key-concepts|dev docs> - especially the <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl|Hubl Template language>, <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/building-blocks/module-theme-fields-overview|module and theme overview> - you'll need them almost every day (especially if you're just starting with development)
• learn <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/if-statements|if-statements>, <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/for-loops|for-loops>, <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/filters|filters>, <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/functions|functions>, <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/variables|variables> and <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/variables-macros-syntax|macros> (a bit on the advanced side but super helpful)
• since Hubl is based upon jinja2 it can be benefitial to look into the <https://jinja.palletsprojects.com/en/3.1.x/|jinja docs> since there might be some things that aren't documented in the Hubl docs but will work :slightly_smiling_face: 
• if you're just starting start with <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/building-blocks/themes/HubSpot-cms-boilerplate|the boilerplate> and development in the design-manager - <https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/developer-reference/local-development-cli|local development> can be a bit overwhelming for beginners but have it's benefits for advanced use-cases. Nontheless it doesn't hurt to take a look at it
• Be creative! Especially if you're just starting. 
• If you haven't already -> create a sign up for the <https://community.HubSpot.com/|HubSpot community>. You can ask specific questions and get help there
Thank you. I have worked with VS code before, so after I learn the basics, I will try to understand how the HubSpot extension works.
<@U03REFNRMB3>, <@U0310AHEKMY>: I’ll cast a little wider net here. Do you have a recording of last Wednesday’s (week 2) bootcamp session? I had a planned absence and need to make up the exercises.

You're welcome!
The HS extension is quite simple "set it and forget it" kinda way if you're working with the terminal :slightly_smiling_face:
Since it would only be me and an outsourced dev company doing work is it better to work in the editor or in the HubSpot dasdboard?

If you're working with external devs it's up to you. You have to come up with a solution that works for both parties. From my experience something like a git-repo would be the best case.
You have a branch, the external devs got a branch and you(since you're the "product owner"/responsible person ) are responsible for merging it all together. The master/main branch will be pushed to HS.
If you don't want to go the git tunnel you could think about a second CMS developer sandbox(you can have as many as you want/need) for the external devs and you'll pull the data from there into your cms dev account, merge it and push it to live account once it's done. Possible but quite a headache and not as performant as github (with actions)

The big downside of almost every mixed(internal and external) environment is: communication. If you don't tell the devs that you've changed something in their code or vice-versa the next push/update will overwrite it. The good thing: You have built-in revisions in HS(don't mentioning Git since it's the main reason for git) so you can always jump back and restore something...

Hey <@U075AMM2N56> thanks for the follow up.

We are working to get the video available for all. Once I get word, I’ll let you know.
